title: Case05 Otosclerosis with Tinnitus
chief_complaint: I have had bothersome ringing in my ears for two years, mostly on the right side. I also have trouble with loud sounds and hearing in background noise.

problem_summary.course: Persistent; continued after stapedectomy surgery one year ago.
problem_summary.laterality: Bilateral hearing loss; tinnitus worse in the right ear.
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Sound sensitivity (hyperacusis), difficulty in background noise.
problem_summary.functional_impact: Moderate tinnitus impairment (THI 56); difficulty ignoring tinnitus to return to activity/sleep.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Seeking relief from tinnitus after previous hearing aids failed to help.

history.present_illness: Patient reports recurrent bothersome tinnitus for 2 years. Previously purchased RIC devices ($4,000) from a dispenser but saw no improvement in tinnitus or hearing after 6 months. Later diagnosed with otosclerosis by an ENT.
history.otologic_history: Diagnosed with otosclerosis. Underwent stapedectomy with prosthetic implant on the right ear 1 year ago. Resulted in partial recovery of low-frequency hearing but persistent tinnitus.
history.medical_psych_history: Hypertension and hypothyroidism (pharmacologically managed). Good general health.
history.prior_management: Previous trial of private-labeled RIC hearing aids (failed). Stapedectomy (Right).
history.patient_goals: Tinnitus relief and management of sound sensitivity.

tests.name: Otoscopy
tests.key_findings: Left ear: Clear, patent canal, normal eardrum. Right ear: Opaque eardrum consistent with surgical history.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Left ear: Normal hearing through 2000 Hz, sloping to mild-to-moderate SNHL at 3000 Hz and above. Right ear: Asymmetric mild-to-severe mixed hearing loss (low-frequency gap visible).

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: SRTs consistent with PTA. Excellent word recognition scores in both ears when tested at 40 dB SL.

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.key_findings: Left ear normal mobility. Right ear reduced compliance consistent with stapedectomy history.

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.key_findings: Pure tone ARTs not assessed due to loudness discomfort. Broadband noise ARTs present for probe-left, absent for probe-right.

tests.name: Loudness Contour Test
tests.key_findings: Reduced tolerance for pure tones in both ears.

tests.name: Tinnitus Assessment
tests.key_findings: Tinnitus matched to high-frequency pure tone. Positive residual inhibition (32 seconds).

tests.name: Self-Report Scales
tests.key_findings: THI indicates moderate handicap. TFI indicates candidacy for Levo system. COAT indicates minimal concern with hearing loss itself.

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presents with asymmetric hearing loss: mild-to-moderate high-frequency SNHL in the left ear and mild-to-severe mixed loss in the right ear (consistent with stapedectomy). Word recognition is excellent bilaterally. Key findings include reduced loudness tolerance (LDLs 80-90 dB HL) and bothersome tinnitus matched to 4000 Hz. Tinnitus assessment shows positive residual inhibition and a Minimum Masking Level of 26 dB SL.
counseling_points: Explain that while the surgery improved low-frequency hearing, the remaining hearing loss and tinnitus are connected.
Discuss the 'Loudness Contour' results, validating your sensitivity to loud sounds (hyperacusis).
Recommend a new trial of amplification combined with sound therapy, specifically designed for tinnitus management (unlike the previous devices).
Introduce biofeedback exercises (progressive muscle relaxation) to help manage the reaction to tinnitus.
Discuss the option of the Levo System for overnight sound therapy given the TFI score of 51.
notes_for_actor: You are 81 but in good health.
You are skeptical about hearing aids because you spent $4,000 previously and they didn't help your tinnitus.
You are sensitive to loud sounds; wince or express discomfort if sounds are too loud during testing.
You hear the ringing mostly in your right ear.
